title-group.article-title: Relationships between Chinese College Test Takers’ Strategy Use and EFL Reading Test Performance: A Structural Equation Modeling Approach

contrib.aff: National Institute of Education, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore
Faculty of Education, The University of Auckland, New Zealand

author-notes.corresp: Lawrence Jun Zhang, School of Curriculum & Pedagogy, Faculty of Education, The University of Auckland, 74 Epsom Ave, Private Bag 92601, Symonds Street, Auckland, 1150, New Zealand. Email: lj.zhang@auckland.ac.nz

abstract.p: This article investigates the relationships between test takers’ strategy use and test performance on an EFL reading test. For this study 209 Chinese college students were invited to participate in a reading comprehension test and answer a 30-item strategy use questionnaire. Results showed that two factors underlay test takers’ reading test performance: lexico-grammatical reading ability (LEX-GR) and text comprehension reading ability (TxtCOM). In addition, metacognitive strategy use had a significant and direct effect on cognitive strategy use, implying that the former performed an executive function over the latter. Monitoring strategies were found to have a significant effect on LEX-GR and evaluating strategies significantly affected TxtCOM, suggesting that metacognitive strategy use played an important role on the reading test. Pedagogical implications are also discussed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Since the 1970s, researchers in English as a second language (ESL)/English as a foreign language (EFL) have shown considerable interest in studying individual characteristics in language learners (Cohen and Macaro, 2007; Ellis, 2008). In particular, one individual difference variable, learner strategy use, has gained increasing attention among researchers. A great number of studies have investigated the relationships between language learner strategy use and language performance (for example, O’Malley and Chamot, 1990; Oxford, 1990; Politzer and McGroarty, 1985; Phakiti, 2003, 2008; Purpura, 1997, 1999; Wen and Johnson, 1997).

In the field of second language (L2) reading, researchers have paid increasing attention to what proficient readers typically do while reading, especially through identifying the strategies they employ (for example, Block, 1986, 1992; Kern, 1989; Macaro and Erler, 2008, Zhang, 2001). The consensus view is that skilled readers use multiple strategies to maximize and facilitate reading comprehension (Zhang, 2010).

Similarly, language testing researchers have shown growing interest in the identification and characterization of the individual characteristics that influence performance on language tests in recent years (Kunnan, 1995; Purpura, 1999). For example, Bachman and Palmer (2010: 35) present a framework in which test takers seem to rely on their strategic competence, ‘a set of metacognitive strategies’, to deal with language and item-response demands.

Despite the fact that more studies have been conducted on mainland Chinese EFL learners in recent years (for example, Gan, Humphreys and Hamp-Lyons, 2004; Song and Cheng, 2006; Wen and Johnson, 1997; Zhang, 2002, 2010), none of them have studied the College English Test Band 4 (CET-4) Reading Subtest which takes 45 percent of the total score of this high-stakes standardized test in China (Jin, 2008). The current study was designed to investigate the relationships between test takers’ strategy use and their reading performance on the test and the trait structure of the EFL reading test performance as measured by the CET-4 Reading Subtest.

sec.title: Bachman and Palmer’s (2010) Framework for Language Use
sec.p: In Bachman and Palmer’s (2010) framework, two sets of test takers’ characteristics are elaborated: focal and peripheral attributes. The focal attribute is the learner’s language ability which comprises language knowledge and strategic competence. Language knowledge involves organizational knowledge (including grammatical and textual knowledge) and pragmatic knowledge (including functional and sociolinguistic knowledge). Strategic competence is viewed as ‘higher-order metacognitive strategies that provide a management function in language use’ (Bachman and Palmer, 2010: 48) and comprises:

list-item.p: goal setting, which involves deciding what the language users would do when facing language use or test tasks;
appraising, through which the individuals associate their topical knowledge and language knowledge with the language use setting and tasks; and
planning, which concerns the individual’s decision of how to use language knowledge, topical knowledge, affective schemata, and cognitive strategies to complete the tasks successfully.

sec.p: Other peripheral attributes of test takers which we need to consider include personal attributes, topical knowledge, affective schemata, and cognitive strategies. Among these attributes, cognitive strategies are perceived as the ways in which language users ‘execute plans in actual language use’ (Bachman and Palmer, 2010: 35). By virtue of these attributes, Bachman and Palmer’s model provides a theoretical framework within which we can investigate the important role of strategies used by language learners in taking language tests.

sec.title: Second Language Reading and Metacognition
sec.p: Considerable research on reading comprehension has shown that comprehension cannot occur without the successful operation of lower-level processes such as word recognition, syntactic parsing, and semantic-proposition encoding (for example, Gough and Tunmer, 1986; Grabe, 2009; LaBerge and Samuels, 1974; Zhang, 2001; Zhang, Gu and Hu, 2008), which are generally termed lexico-grammatical knowledge (Celce-Murcia and Larsen-Freeman, 1999; Purpura, 2004).

Furthermore, recent literature on both L1 and L2 reading research shows that reading is a constructive process in which the text, the reader, and the context interact (Carrell, 1989; Paris and Hamilton, 2009). The reader reconstructs the text information based on his word processing knowledge (i.e. lexico-grammatical knowledge) and his knowledge about the world or his schemata (for example, Afflerbach, Pearson and Paris, 2008; Block, 1992; Macaro and Erler, 2008; Zhang and Annual, 2008). In this meaning-constructing process of comprehension, metacognition plays the role of a fixer or problem solver, maximizing comprehension of the text and repairing comprehension failure by using the toolbox of strategies (Pearson, 2009; Zhang, 2010). Numerous studies have shown that the relationship between metacognition and reading comprehension has long been established (see Brown, 1980; Carrell, 1989; Paris, Lipson and Wixson, 1983; Phakiti, 2008; Sheorey and Mokhtari, 2001; Zhang, 2008; among others).

Metacognition refers to the knowledge of cognitive processes and products and includes reflecting on one’s own thoughts or cognition about cognition (Flavell, 1979). Flavell (1978) divided metacognitive knowledge into learners’ knowledge of variables related to learners themselves, learning tasks and strategies. Brown (1978) further categorized metacognition into planning, monitoring, and revising one’s thinking. Now the consensus view among researchers is a blend of the twin approaches to metacognition: knowledge of cognition and regulation of cognition (Baker and Brown, 1984; Flavell, Miller and Miller, 2002). Knowledge of cognition refers to one’s knowledge about his cognitive resources when involved in academic tasks, which is ‘stable and stateable’ information (Baker and Brown, 1984: 353). Regulation of cognition is concerned about the learners’ ‘self-regulatory mechanisms’ used while attempting to solve problems (Baker and Brown, 1984: 354). Drawing on Brown, Bransford, Ferrara, and Campione (1983), Wenden (1998) wrote that self-regulatory skills would include planning, monitoring, and evaluating. This distinction was adopted by O’Malley and Chamot (1990) in their taxonomy of language learning strategies and is consistent with Jacobs and Paris’ (1987) tripartite conception of metacognition comprising planning, evaluation, and regulation. Planning concerns selecting particular actions to realize the goals that have been set; evaluating refers to assessing the tasks and one’s personal cognitive abilities; and monitoring involves checking and regulating one’s thinking and performance during the course of completing the cognitive activities in order to reach the desired goals (Phakiti, 2008).

sec.title: Language Learner Strategy Use and Language Performance
sec.p: Based on the various definitions and categories of learner strategies, a considerable number of studies have investigated the relationships between strategy use and language performance. A generalized conclusion from these studies is that more advanced or proficient language learners use strategies more frequently, flexibly, and appropriately (Anderson, 1991; O’Malley and Chamot, 1990; Vann and Abraham, 1990; Zhang, 2010). From methodological perspectives, these studies have employed a spectrum of methods, such as observation (Rubin, 1981), think-aloud verbal report (Anderson, 1989; Cohen, 1984), interviews (Huang and van Naerssen, 1985; Wenden and Rubin, 1987) and questionnaires (Carrell, 1989; Phakiti, 2003, 2008; Politzer and McGroarty, 1985; Purpura, 1997, 1999; Sheorey and Mokhtari, 2001, 2008; Zhang, 2002; see Zhang, 2003, for a review of studies on Chinese EFL learners; see Oxford, 2011, for a recent update).

Among the studies using questionnaires, Purpura’s (1997, 1999) work is different from the previous ones in the sense that it was not only rooted in human information processing theory, but also investigated the psychometric characteristics of the questionnaire thoroughly. Purpura (1997) used structural equation modeling to examine the relationships between test takers’ strategy use and test performance on the University of Cambridge First Certificate of English (FCE) Anchor Test with 1,382 EFL participants. His 40-item cognitive questionnaire included 11 strategy-type variables representing 3 underlying processing variables: comprehending, memory, and retrieval which reflected the stages of human learning processes (Gagnè, Yekovich and Yekovich, 1993). In the comprehending stage, learners hold the new information in their working memory long enough to transform it into meaningful symbols; in the memory stage, they elaborate the information to make connections and recognize patterns for the storage of the information in their long-term memory; and in the retrieval stage, learners withdraw the information from their long-term memory for use. The 40-item metacognitive questionnaire involved 4 strategy-type variables (i.e. assessing the situation, monitoring, self-evaluating, and self-testing) and 2 underlying process type variables (i.e. on-line and post assessment processes). As shown in the study, two underlying factors explained the second language test performance (SLTP): reading ability (RDG ABILITY) and grammar ability (GRAM ABILITY). Purpura’s (1997) study showed that metacognitive strategy use had no direct effect on language performance, but it was closely related to and exerted an executive function over cognitive strategy use.

Song (2005) abridged Purpura’s (1999) questionnaire into a 43-item questionnaire (i.e. 27 cognitive strategy and 16 metacognitive strategy use items) and administered it to 161 test-takers taking the Michigan English Language Assessment Battery (MELAB). The result showed that MELAB test takers’ use of metacognitive strategies had three categories: evaluating, monitoring, and assessing. Song and Cheng (2006) used another condensed version of Purpura’s questionnaire consisting of 34 items of cognitive and 30 items of metacognitive strategies. They assigned it to 121 Chinese college test takers taking the CET-4. Their study showed that CET-4 test takers used more metacognitive strategies than cognitive strategies.

Phakiti (2003) developed a 35-item questionnaire including items similar to Purpura’s (1999) to examine the relationships between 384 Thai test takers’ strategy use and reading test performance. The cognitive strategy questionnaire comprised two factors: comprehending and retrieval; and metacognitive strategies two factors: planning and monitoring. His study concluded that the use of cognitive and metacognitive strategies had a positive but weak relationship with the reading performance, which explained 15 to 22% of the test score variance.

Based on human information processing theory (Gagnè et al., 1993), Phakiti (2008) developed a 30-item strategy questionnaire and validated Bachman and Palmer’s (1996) theory of strategic competence with 561 Thai university students on an EFL reading test. His questionnaire was composed of 13 items of cognitive strategies and 17 items of metacognitive strategies. The two underlying factors of the EFL reading test were lexico-grammatical reading ability (LEX-GR) and text comprehension reading ability (TxtCOM). The findings of this study corroborated Purpura’s (1997, 1999) in that metacognitive strategy use had a direct effect on cognitive strategy use. In addition, this study indicated that LEX-GR affected TxtCOM directly and significantly. The foregoing literature review has generated the implications as follows:

list-item.p: Lexico-grammatical ability is directly related to L2 reading ability. That is, test takers’ knowledge of word recognition and syntactic parsing is expected to affect their reading ability greatly and directly.
Both cognitive and metacognitive strategy use have direct relationships to test takers’ demonstration of lexico-grammatical ability as well as reading ability.
Metacognitive strategy use has a direct effect on cognitive strategy use. In other words, metacognitive strategy use is supposed to exert an executive management function on cognitive strategy use.

sec.title: Research Questions and Hypotheses
sec.p: Based on the literature review, we postulated the SEM model which intends to answer the following research questions:

list-item.p: What is the trait structure of the test-takers’ cognitive and metacognitive strategy use?
What is the trait structure of the EFL reading test performance as measured by the CET-4 Reading Subtest?
What is the relationship among test takers’ reading test performance, cognitive and metacognitive strategy use?

sec.p: First, considering that we chose Phatiki’s (2008) questionnaire which was designed specifically for the EFL reading test and had been subjected to vigorous validation processes, we hypothesized that the trait structure of the cognitive and metacognitive strategy use on the EFL reading test in the current study would follow the same pattern as that found by Phakiti (2008). As suggested in Phakiti’s study, comprehending, memory and retrieval strategies were hypothesized to load on cognitive strategy use; and planning, monitoring, and evaluating strategies were supposed to load on metacognitive strategy use. Metacognitive strategy use was hypothesized to have a direct effect on cognitive strategy use (see Figure 1).

caption.p: Hypothesized Trait Structure of Cognitive and Metacognitive Strategy Use

Note. COG = cognitive strategy scale; META= metacognitive strategy scale. COM= comprehending strategies. MEM= memory strategies. RET= retrieval strategies. PLA= planning strategies. EVA=evaluating strategies. MON= monitoring strategies. E1to E6= Error 1 to 6. D1= Disturbance 11.

sec.p: Second, on the basis of the literature review above, we hypothesized that the EFL reading test performance had two underlying factors: text comprehension reading ability (TxtCOM) and lexico-grammatical reading ability (LEX-GR). LEX-GR had a direct effect on TxtCOM. According to the test syllabus of the CET-4 (National College English Testing Committee, 2006), specific skills assessed in the reading test include: a) the ability to distinguish and understand main ideas and important details; b) the ability to understand the passage by means of language skills. The former is represented by passage comprehension items in Skimming and Scanning (SKSM) and Reading in Depth (RID) sections, whereas the latter is operationalized by cloze items in Banked Cloze (BCLZ) and Multiple-Choice Cloze (MCLZ) sections. Additionally, contrary to an earlier assertion that cloze tests measured higher order processing abilities (Hinofotis, 1980; Oller, 1979), more recent studies have shown that cloze tests served as a measure of lower order proficiency such as grammar and vocabulary (Alderson, 1979; Markham, 1985; Purpura, 1999, 2004; Saito, 2003; Shanahan, Kamil and Tobin, 1982). Therefore, we hypothesized that SKSM and RID loaded on TxtCOM while BCLZ and MCLZ on LEX-GR (see Figure 2).

caption.p: Hypothesized Trait Structure of the EFL Reading Test Performance

Note. TxtCOM= text comprehension ability. LEX-GR= Lexico-Grammatical reading ability. SKSM=Skimming and Scanning. RID= Reading in Depth. BCLZ = Banked Cloze. MCLZ = Multiple-Choice Cloze. E1to E4 = Error 1 to 4. D1= Disturbance 1.

sec.p: Third, based on the previous review of the literature, we hypothesized that cognitive and metacognitive strategy use would have corresponding effects on both TxtCOM and LEX-GR. Additionally, comprehending, memory, retrieval, planning, monitoring, and evaluating strategies were hypothesized to have individual direct effects on TxtCOM and LEX-GR (see Figure 3).

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: We administered a published CET-4 Reading Subtest (the June 2010 version) and the reading strategy questionnaire (Phakiti, 2008) to 209 college students aged between 17 and 23 (M=19.71, SD=1.08) in two government-funded universities in mainland China. Participants were 101 male (48.3%) and 105 female (50.2%) students and 3 others who did not indicate their gender (1.43%). Since we did not take into consideration gender differences in our study, we included all the 209 participants in our data analysis. On average, they had 9.98 years of formal English instructions (SD=2.19) by the time of the study. None of the participants had practiced the June 2010 version of the CET-4 Reading Subtest.

sec.title: Instruments
sec.p: The instruments used in the study were one strategy use questionnaire based on Phakiti (2008) and one reading comprehension test (the CET-4 Reading Subtest).

sec.title: Strategy Use Questionnaire
sec.p: Phakiti’s questionnaire (2008) was employed to measure test takers’ reported strategy use on the test (see Appendix A). There were 30 items in the questionnaire designed on a 6-point Likert scale: 0 (never), 1 (rarely), 2 (sometimes), 3 (often), 4 (usually) and 5 (always). According to Phakiti (2008), the items were chosen on the basis of his review of studies on language learners’ use of strategies reported in the literature (Cohen, 1998; Hsiao and Oxford, 2002; Mokhtari and Sheorey, 2002; O’Malley and Chamot, 1990; Oxford, 1990; Phakiti, 2003; Purpura, 1999) and based on human information processing theory (Gagnè et al., 1993).

The questionnaire comprises two parts: cognitive and metacognitive strategies. Cognitive strategies are the actual behaviours consciously used by students to process language in the specific contexts while metacognitive strategies pertain to the conscious processes employed by learners to manage cognitive processing (Phakiti, 2008; Purpura, 1999). There are three underlying factors for the cognitive strategies: comprehending (4 items), memory (4 items), and retrieval (5 items), and three for the metacognitive strategies: planning (6 items), monitoring (5 items), and evaluating (6 items) (see Table 1 for items under each subscale).

caption.p: Taxonomy of Cognitive and Metacognitive Strategies

sec.p: Following Phakiti (2008), comprehending strategies are those used for understanding the text, such as identifying the main idea, making inferences, and translating, among others; memory strategies are for storing information, including rereading, note-taking, or paraphrasing; and retrieval strategies are used for recalling information, such as using prior knowledge or applying grammatical rules, etc. Planning strategies are employed to plan future actions and attain goals, such as setting goals, directing tasks; monitoring strategies are those students use to check their ongoing comprehension and test-taking processes, such as double-checking comprehension and test performance, noticing comprehension failure, and so on; and evaluating strategies are used to assess and evaluate students’ actions and performance in the reading comprehension test, such as self-questioning, evaluating the accuracy of comprehension, etc. To suit the current study, item 8 ‘I tried to understand the content of the text and tasks without looking up every word’ was deleted because the CET-4 test takers are not allowed to use dictionaries of any kind.

sec.title: CET-4 Reading Subtest
sec.p: The College English Test (CET), administered by the National College English Testing Committee (NCETC) on behalf of the Chinese Ministry of Education, includes two levels: Band 4 and Band 6. In this study, we used the published version of the June 2010 CET-4 Reading Subtest, which comprises 50 items, including 10 skimming and scanning items, 10 banked cloze items, 10 items measuring reading in depth, and 20 multiple choice (MC) cloze items. Test takers were required to complete the reading test within 55 minutes.

sec.title: Data Collection, Scoring, and Preparation
sec.p: The consent form and the questionnaire were translated into Chinese before being administered to the participants to ensure their accurate understanding. All 50 test items on the CET-4 Reading Subtest were scored dichotomously with only one key to each question. We marked and double-checked every answer to ensure all the items were scored accurately. Then we input all the data into the IBM SPSS Statistics Version 20 computer program for further analysis.

sec.title: Descriptive statistics
sec.p: We examined the descriptive statistics and checked the assumption about normality. We calculated the means, standard deviation, skewness, and kurtosis of the test and questionnaire at the item level as well as the subscale and the section levels. All values of skewness and kurtosis were checked to ensure that they were within the accepted range (± 2) for a normal distribution (Bachman, 2004). We investigated the internal consistency of the test and the questionnaire at the section and subscale levels. Guttman’s split-half procedure was employed for calculating the reliability estimates for the reading test because the assumption of independence may be violated in the reading comprehension items (Bachman, 1990; Purpura, 1999).

sec.title: Confirmatory factor analysis
sec.p: In confirmatory factor analysis (CFA), researchers attempt to test the significance of a hypothesized factor model by examining whether the sample data confirm the proposed model. Since sufficient theoretical support has been provided in Phakiti (2008), we used CFA to assess the fit of the model of cognitive and metacognitive strategy use to our data. CFA was conducted separately with cognitive and metacognitive strategy use because they are distinct constructs of strategy use according to empirical studies (Brown et al., 1983; Phakiti, 2008; Song and Cheng, 2006). Based on the postulated structure of the questionnaire, we proposed two second order CFA models for cognitive and metacognitive strategy use respectively. We hypothesized that comprehending, memory, and retrieval strategies loaded significantly on cognitive strategy use, whereas planning, monitoring, and evaluating strategies had significant loadings on metacognitive strategy use. All observed variables (items) were hypothesized to load on their corresponding unobserved variables (subscales) significantly.

Similarly, we did CFA analyses with the test at the level of individual items to gather the preliminary evidence for our hypothesized trait structure of the EFL test performance. We hypothesized a CFA model with four factors: skimming and scanning (SKSC), reading in-depth (RID), bank-cloze (BCLZ), and multiple choice cloze (MCLZ) based on the CET-4 test specification. Each item in the corresponding section was hypothesized to load on its postulated factor significantly.

Two incremental fit indices Comparative Fit Index (CFI) and the Non-Normed Fit Index (NNFI) were used as indices of comparative fit. These indices assess the relative improvement of the tested model compared with the null model. CFI and NNFI of equal to or greater than .90 are indicative of reasonably good model fit (Hu and Bentler, 1999). The ratio of Chi-square divided by the degree of freedom (df), its p-value, and the Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA) were used as the indices of absolute fit. Chi-square tests the closeness of fit between the observed and predicted covariance matrix. A Chi-square/ df of less than 3 indicates a good model fit. RMSEA is supposed to be minimally influenced by sample size and the estimation method (Fan, Thompson and Wang, 1999). RMSEA of less than .08 represents reasonable error of approximation (Browne and Cudeck, 1993). RMSEA 90% confidence interval was also reported. The narrower interval suggests better model fit (Byrne, 2001).

On the basis of the result of CFA tests, we generated composite variables at the subscale and section levels for further SEM analyses. This technique is termed item-parceling (Bandalos and Finney, 2001; Little, Cunningham, Shahar, and Widaman, 2002), which is commonly used in latent variable analyses (Kunnan, 1998; Purpura, 1999).

sec.title: SEM analyses
sec.p: Structural equation modeling (SEM) is a powerful statistical technique to test different theoretical models which demonstrate how a set of observed variables define latent variables and the relationships among these variables (Schumacker and Lomax, 2004; Kline, 2010). In language testing, a growing number of studies have adopted this methodology, especially in investigating learners’ strategy use and test structure (In’nami and Koizumi, 2011; Kunnan, 1998). In the current study, we employed SEM to examine the hypothesized relationships between test takers’ strategy use and test performance which are represented in the proposed SEM model (see Figure 3).

After testing the measurement models and establishing the relationships between the observed and latent variables, we proceeded to test structural models with directional relationships among the factors. In the whole process of model positing and testing, we aimed at both statistical and substantive plausibility. We used IBM SPSS AMOS computer program Version 20.0 (Arbuckle, 2011) to perform the analyses. Maximum Likelihood (ML) was chosen as the method of parameter estimation. The fit indices used to test the model fit were consistent with those adopted for CFA analyses.

sec.title: Descriptive Statistics and Reliability Analyses
sec.p: The distribution for the test and questionnaire at the item level as well as subscale and section levels was calculated. All values of skewness and kurtosis were within the accepted range (± 2) for a normal distribution. The internal consistency of the questionnaire and the test at the subscale and section levels was also calculated (see Tables 2 and 3).

sec.p: The reliability estimates of the questionnaire and test were .86 and .81 respectively. The reliabilities of the subscale level of the questionnaire varied from .34 to .78. Considering the fact that there were relatively few items in the subscales, we decided to keep them for further analyses. The reliabilities of the section level of the test varied from .59 to .83. Although the reliability for the Reading in Depth section was relatively low (.59), the whole test proved to be a reliable one (.81). Therefore, we decided to keep all questionnaire and test items for later analyses.

sec.title: Confirmatory Factor Analysis
sec.p: In the CFA models for cognitive and metacognitive strategy use, the first-order factor which includes comprehending, memory, and retrieval strategies, loaded significantly on cognitive strategy use with standardized coefficients .90, .82 and .98, and planning, monitoring, and evaluating strategies loaded significantly on metacognitive strategy use with .90, .82, and .98 respectively. Besides, all path coefficients from first-order factors to the corresponding observed variables were significant at the .05 level, indicating that the observed variables were reliable measures of what were hypothesized to measure. Additionally, the fit indices (see Table 4) showed that both models had good model fit, with NNFI and CFI above .90, and RMSEA below .08. All these lent support to Phakiti’s (2008) questionnaire being a valid instrument in our study.

In the four-factor model, the four factors correlated with one another, with correlation coefficients ranging from .60 to .81. sec.title: SEM Analyses
sec.p: In SEM analyses, we found the structural model did not converge based on our data. We assumed that this might be caused by statistical as well as theoretical factors. Statistically, considering the complexity of the proposed model and the methodology used, our limited sample size seemed to lead to the non-convergence. Additionally, in the actual situation of the high-stakes test, it was the individual and specific strategy rather than the abstract cognitive or metacognitive strategy use that most likely enhances test takers’ performance. Thus we modified the model by deleting the paths from COG and META to TxtCOM and LEX-GR. The modified model converged with good model fit indices (see Table 6). The NNFI and CFI were all above .90; RMSEA below .08, and Chi-square /df 1.83. We concluded that this model represented our data well statistically and substantively.

sec.title: Trait Structure of Cognitive and Metacognitive Strategy Use
sec.p: In our study we employed Phakiti’s (2008) questionnaire to explore 209 Chinese college test-takers’ strategy use on the CET-4 Reading Subtest. As shown in Figure 4, comprehending, memory, and retrieval strategies loaded heavily and significantly on cognitive strategy use with values of .74, .60 and .61; and planning, monitoring, and evaluating strategies had similar high and significant loadings on metacognitive strategy use with values of .73, .59 and .76, indicating they were good measures of cognitive and metacognitive strategy use respectively.

caption.p: Illustration of the Hypothesized Trait Structure of Cognitive and Metacognitive Strategy Use

Note. COG = cognitive strategy scale; META= metacognitive strategy scale. COM= comprehending strategies. MEM= memory strategies. RET= retrieval strategies. PLA= planning strategies. EVA= evaluating strategies. MON= monitoring strategies. Figures shown are standardized regression coefficients. E1to E6= Error 1 to 6. D1= Disturbance 1

sec.p: Consistent with Phakiti’s (2008) study, we found that metacognitive strategy use had a direct and significant effect on cognitive strategy use with a high coefficient of .83. This finding corroborated the results of several empirical studies (for example, Bachman and Palmer, 1996; Færch and Kasper, 1983; O’ Malley and Chamot, 1990; Phakiti, 2003, 2008; Purpura, 1997, 1999). Phakiti (2003) concluded that metacognitive strategy use was correlated with cognitive strategy use at .608, whereas Hatch and Lazaraton (1991) reported a higher correlation between them (r=.761). This study provided further evidence that test takers’ metacognitive strategy use performed an executive function over their cognitive strategy use.

sec.title: Trait Structure of the EFL Reading Test Performance
sec.p: In our tested model, two underlying factors explained the EFL reading test performance: lexico-grammatical ability (LEX-GR) and text comprehension ability (TxtCOM). LEX-GR had a direct and significant effect on TxtCOM with a high regression coefficient of .95 (see Figure 5). This finding is consistent with an array of similar studies such as Phakiti (2008), Purpura (1997), and Saito (2003). In Phakiti’s longitudinal study about the EFL reading test, the value was .99 and .82 in the Time 1 and Time 2 situations respectively. In Purpura’s and Sato’s studies on the second language test performance (SLTP), lexico-grammatical ability directly and significantly affected reading ability with a high value of .985 and .95, respectively.

caption.p: Illustration of Hypothesized Trait Structure of EFL Reading Test Performance

Note. TxtCOM= text comprehension ability. LEX-GR= Lexico-Grammatical reading ability. SKSM=Skimming and Scanning. RID= Reading in Depth. BCLZ = Banked Cloze. MCLZ = Multiple-Choice Cloze. E1to E4 = Error 1 to 4. D1= Disturbance 1. Figures shown are standardized regression coefficients.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 5, SKSM and RID loaded significantly and heavily on TxtCOM with coefficients of .79 and .62. LEX-GR was well measured by test takers’ performance on BCLZ and MCLZ sections with a relative high and significant loading of .70 and .83. After the major revision of the CET-4 in 2007, the Vocabulary and Structure section was replaced by the Banked Cloze section because contextualized language use had been paid more attention in lieu of context-free knowledge of language (Jin, 2008; National College English Testing Committee, 2006). In our analysis, the high loading of the BCLZ section on LEX-GR seemed to show that the new test format had played an expected role in tapping into test takers’ lexco-grammatical reading ability. Similarly, the new test format of skimming and scanning also appeared to be a valid part to assess college test takers’ text comprehension ability, as shown in our analysis.

However, we found that LEX-GR predicted TxtCOM perfectly as measured by the CET-4 Reading Subtest, suggesting that test takers’ performance on the reading comprehension test was highly dependent on their ability to understand text at the lexical and grammatical level, i.e. their bottom-up rather than top-down processing which comprises a set of higher-level skills such as inference-making and integration (Grabe, 2009; Kintsch, 1998; cf. Zhang, 2010) etc. Additionally, compared with RID, which is supposed to tap into test takers’ higher level skills in reading, SKSM loaded more heavily on TxtCOM, indicating more variance explained by this section. Therefore, based on our analysis, at least for the present sample, we conclude that as an EFL reading test the CET-4 Reading Subtest assessed test takers’ fundamental reading skills.

sec.title: Strategy Use and the Test Performance on the CET-4 Reading Subtest
sec.p: We found that the three subscales of cognitive strategies, including comprehending, memory, and retrieving strategies, all had low and non-significant effects on LEX-GR and TxtCOM. Comprehending strategies even had the lowest and negative effect on TxtCOM (-.09), as shown in Figure 6 (see also Appendix B). A close examination of the three comprehending strategy items showed that they were concerned with ‘I tried to understand the relationships between ideas in the text and tasks’ (item 7), ‘I thought what was going to happen next while reading’ (item 9), and ‘I analyzed what the author meant’ (item 10). Considering the time pressure in this high-stakes test, it is understandable that the more time test takers spend concentrating on the text itself rather than tackling the tasks, the worse their performance would be. This conclusion is consistent with Purpura’s (1999: 129) study which showed that COM (comprehending) processes had ‘an extremely low, direct, negative influence (-0.023)’ on lexico-grammatical ability.

sec.p: Similarly, we found that memory and retrieval strategies also had negligible effects on LEX-GR and TxtCOM. These findings provide empirical support for the notion that not all strategies enhance language performance in testing situations. For example, Wen and Johnson (1997) concluded that tolerating-ambiguity strategies had a negative effect on language performance in general learning situations. Therefore, we concur with Song (2005: 19) that strategy use is ‘dependent on the nature of different tasks and contributing differently to language performance’.

As Figure 6 indicates, we had some interesting findings regarding metacognitive strategy subscales of planning, monitoring, and evaluating. We found that planning had no significant effects on either LEX-GR or TxtCOM. However, our analyses showed that monitoring strategies had a positive and significant effect on LEX-GR, with a value of .18, but they had a negative and marginally significant effect on TxtCOM, with a coefficient of -.14. The monitoring items include ‘I was aware of the time limitations in the test’ (item 20), ‘I knew how much of the reading and test tasks remained to be done’ (item 21), ‘I knew when I lost concentration’ (item 24), ‘I noticed when and where I was confused’ (item 29), and ‘I knew when I felt worried, tense or unmotivated to complete the test’. The prevailing reading theories (Alderson, 1979; Grabe, 2009) and our common sense suggest that readers tend to focus more on the lower order skills of grammar and vocabulary in completing cloze tests. But in dealing with the passage reading tasks, test takers will have to achieve better comprehension of the text before they are able to answer test items correctly.

Considering the contents of the monitoring strategy items, we think it is reasonable to conclude that if test takers were constantly aware of the time limits and conscious of their affective changes in answering passage reading questions in SKSM and RID sections, they would not be able to concentrate on the more demanding comprehension tasks to perform well. But in cloze tests, since the tasks tend to be easier and comprise more items which require better time management strategies, the monitoring strategies contributed to test takers’ performance significantly. Our results corroborate Song’s (2005) findings which showed that monitoring strategy use was a strong positive predictor of the MELAB test. Additionally, we found that evaluating strategies had a positive and significant effect on TxtCOM, with the coefficient of .17, but they affected LEX-GR negatively and non-significantly. Further examination of the evaluating items showed that these strategies are concerned with comprehension of the text which is more likely to contribute to better performance of the passage comprehension items instead of cloze tasks. These findings are congruent with Wen and Johnson (1997), who concluded that management strategies (metacognitive strategies) had positive effects on Chinese English majors’ test performance. Besides, it also provided empirical evidence for Paris’ (2002) conclusion that metacognitive strategies can have positive, negative or no effect on reading comprehension.

sec.title: Conclusions and Recommendations
sec.p: The findings from our current study showed that two highly-related factors underlay EFL readers’ test performance: LEX-GR and TxtCOM. Consistent with other similar studies, we found that metacognitive strategy use had an executive function over cognitive strategy use. Monitoring strategies had a significant effect on LEX-GR and evaluating strategies significantly affected TxtCOM. These findings suggest that metacognition played an important role in test-takers performance on the CET-4 Reading Subtest. Additionally, our study provided empirical evidence for Bachman and Palmer’s (2010) model in that the significant role of metacognitive strategy use in the high-stakes test as found in our study proved the plausibility of perceiving strategic competence as a set of metacognitive strategies, whereas cognitive strategies were only viewed as test takers’ peripheral attributes.

As shown in the previous sections, this study has produced some interesting findings. However, the study’s main limitation is the relatively small sample size. Future research in this area could be done to validate the results of the current study with a larger sample obtained from the same or similar population or learning conditions. Additionally, test takers’ strategy use for each of the four test sections could be investigated more closely. That is, instead of calibrating their strategy use in relation to the overall reading test, researchers could require test takers to report their strategy use in each specific section of the reading comprehension test. More importantly, although our analyses showed that Phakiti’s (2008) questionnaire appeared to be a valid instrument in the current study, there still exist demographic differences between the subjects in these two studies. Therefore, a questionnaire designed specifically for the CET-4 test takers is in urgent demand, in which more items seem to be needed to investigate the complex relationships between test takers’ strategy use and test performance. Such a recommendation might also have implications for government agencies in charge of test development and test-takers in other countries, particularly in Asia-Pacific where high-stakes tests are highly regarded by students, schools, parents and the public at large. Pedagogically, our findings suggest that teachers in the classroom might need to take into consideration timely provision of metacognitive and cognitive strategies in their teaching. Such strategy-based instruction is expected to facilitate test takers’ performance on high-stakes tests because of a possibility that it can connect them explicitly with test-taking strategies.

app.title: Appendix A: Phakiti’s (2008) Strategy Use Questionnaire
app.p: Directions: Read each statement and indicate how you actually thought when taking this reading test. Choose 0 (never), 1 (rarely), 2 (sometimes), 3 (often), 4 (usually) or 5 (always) on each statement that best describes how you thought.

list-item.p: I planned what to do before I began to complete this reading test.
I made sure I clarified the goals of the reading test task.
I considered essential steps needed to complete the reading test.
I made sure I understood what had to be done and how to do it.
I knew what to do if my intended plan did not work efficiently while completing this reading test.
I flipped through the reading test before I actually started to complete it.
I tried to understand the relationships between ideas in the text and tasks.
I tried to understand the content without looking up every word.
I thought what was going to happen next while I was reading the text.
I analyzed what the author meant or tried to say in the text.
I tried to interpret hidden ideas/meanings in the texts.
I translated the text, tasks or questions into my first language.
I summarized the main information in the text.
I related the information from the text or tasks to my prior knowledge or experience.
I reread texts or tasks several times when I felt I did not understand them.
I knew which information was more or less important.
I identified or guessed meanings of unknown words using context clues.
I applied my learned grammar rules while reading and completing the reading tasks.
I guessed meanings of unknown words using root words.
I was aware of the time limitations and constraints in this test.
I knew how much of the reading and test tasks remained to be done while taking the test.
I checked if I understood the texts and reading tasks.
I knew when I felt worried, tense or unmotivated to complete this reading test.
I checked my own performance and progress as I moved along the test tasks.
I knew when I lost concentration while completing this test.
I evaluated my plans or goals of my reading tasks constantly.
I knew when I should read or complete the test more carefully.
I double-checked my reading comprehension or performance.
I immediately corrected my misunderstanding or performance mistakes when found.
I noticed when and where I was confused in the text.
